questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a butterfly-shaped rash on her face, fatigue, and joint pain for the past 2 months. Laboratory results show positive antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and low complement levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): The patient's presentation of malar rash, fatigue, joint pain, and positive ANA with low complement levels is classic for SLE.The most common acute SLE rash is a photosensitive, slightly raised, occasionally scaly erythema on the face (particularly the cheeks and nose-the 'butterfly' rash), ears, chin, V region of the neck and chest, upper back, and extensor surfaces of the arms. Worsening of this rash often accompanies flare of systemic disease.


Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): This patient's butterfly-shaped rash (malar rash), fatigue, joint pain, positive ANA, and low complement levels strongly suggest SLE. SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs. Other clinical features may include renal involvement, neurologic symptoms, and hematologic abnormalities. The hallmark laboratory finding is a positive ANA, which is seen in over 95% of patients with SLE. Complement levels (C3, C4) are often decreased due to immune complex formation.


Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis:Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) typically causes symmetric joint inflammation and morning stiffness, usually affecting the small joints (e.g., hands, wrists). It is not associated with a malar rash or low complement levels. ANA positivity can be seen in RA, but it is not diagnostic.

Option B: Dermatomyositis:Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that affects the muscles and skin, presenting with a heliotrope rash around the eyes and muscle weakness. The absence of muscle weakness in this patient makes this diagnosis less likely.


Option D: Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically presents with silvery plaques and erythematous patches on extensor surfaces, not a malar rash. Psoriasis is also not associated with systemic symptoms like joint pain and low complement levels.


Key Takeaway:

  • SLE is an autoimmune disorder that affects multiple organ systems, characterized by malar rash, fatigue, polyarthritis, and positive ANA with low complement levels. It should be suspected in patients presenting with these clinical and laboratory findings.
  • Diagnostic Criteria: To diagnose SLE, patients need to meet a combination of clinical and laboratory criteria (often using the SLICC or ACR criteria).
  • Immune Complexes: Deposition of immune complexes (anti-dsDNA and complement) is central to the pathogenesis of renal and vascular
  • Autoantibodies: Anti-dsDNA and Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for SLE, and low complement levels (C3, C4) often indicate active disease.
  • Complications: Include lupus nephritis, thrombosis (especially with antiphospholipid antibodies), and cardiovascular disease.
  • Treatment: Typically involves immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., corticosteroids, hydroxychloroquine, or biologics like belimumab).

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page number.2740

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a dry cough, fatigue, and occasional shortness of breath for the past three months. Physical examination reveals mild bilateral crackles on lung auscultation. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Laboratory results reveal the following: Serum calcium: 11.2 mg/dL (normal: 8.5-10.2 mg/dL),Serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE): elevated, PPD skin test: negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory granulomatous disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas in multiple organs, most commonly affecting the lungs and lymph nodes. It presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray, which is a hallmark feature of the disease. Other common findings include elevated ACE levels and hypercalcemia due to granuloma-induced overproduction of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D.

  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is a hallmark feature.
  • Elevated ACE levels are found in about 60% of patients with sarcoidosis.
  • Hypercalcemia is caused by increased production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D by activated macrophages in granulomas.
  • Non-caseating granulomas (non-necrotizing) are a histologic hallmark of sarcoidosis, as opposed to the caseating granulomas of tuberculosis.

Sarcoidosis most commonly affects the lungs, but can involve almost any organ, including the skin, eyes, heart, and central nervous system.



Option A: Tuberculosis

Tuberculosis can present with cough and systemic symptoms, but it is usually associated with cavitary lesions or pleural effusion on imaging, not bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

Additionally, the patient's negative PPD test makes active tuberculosis less likely.

Furthermore, tuberculosis presents with caseating granulomas, while sarcoidosis presents with non-caseating granulomas.

Option C: Hodgkin's lymphoma

Hodgkin's lymphoma can present with lymphadenopathy, but it typically involves unilateral lymphadenopathy, often associated with B symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and weight loss.

Additionally, hypercalcemia and elevated ACE levels are not common findings in Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option D: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis results from an immune reaction to inhaled antigens and presents with diffuse interstitial lung disease on imaging, rather than bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Hypercalcemia and elevated ACE levels are also not seen in this condition.

Mnemonic for Sarcoidosis:

'GRANULOMAS':

  • G: Granulomas (non-caseating)
  • R: Rheumatologic features (arthritis, erythema nodosum)
  • A: ACE levels elevated
  • N: No caseation (non-caseating granulomas)
  • U: Uveitis (eye involvement)
  • L: Lymphadenopathy (bilateral hilar)
  • O: Organ involvement (lungs, skin, heart, etc.)
  • M: Multisystem disease
  • A: African Americans at higher risk
  • S: Steroids (first-line treatment for severe or symptomatic disease)

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine,21st edition, page no.2831

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of severe pain, swelling, and redness in his right big toe. He reports that the pain began overnight and has been progressively worsening. He has a history of hypertension and takes hydrochlorothiazide. Laboratory results reveal a serum uric acid level of 10.5 mg/dL (normal: 3.5-7.2 mg/dL). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Gout

The patient's presentation is classic for acute gout, characterized by sudden onset of severe pain, swelling, and erythema of the affected joint, most commonly the big toe. His elevated serum uric acid level and use of a thiazide diuretic, which increases uric acid levels, are further supportive of this diagnosis.

Key Features of Gout:

  • Cause: Deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints due to hyperuricemia.
  • Symptoms: Sudden onset of severe pain, swelling, erythema, and warmth of the affected joint, most commonly the big toe (podagra).
  • Triggers: Often triggered by alcohol intake, high-purine foods (like red meat, seafood), trauma, or the use of diuretics.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed with joint aspiration showing needle-shaped crystals with negative birefringence under polarized light microscopy.
  • Management: Acute attacks are treated with NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids. Long-term management includes uric acid-lowering therapy (e.g., allopurinol, febuxostat) to prevent future attacks.

First metatarsophalangeal joint


Polarized light microscopy Gout vs Pseudogout.



  1. Extracellular and intracellular monosodium urate crystals, as seen in a fresh preparation of synovial fluid, illustrate needle- and rod-shaped crystals (400×). These crystals are strongly negative birefringent crystals under compensated polarized light microscopy.
  2. Intracellular and extracellular calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals, as seen in a fresh preparation of synovial fluid, illustrate rectangular, rod-shaped, and rhomboid crystals (400×). These crystals are weakly positively or nonbirefringent crystals under compensated polarized light microscopy

Gout is a crystal-induced arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints. It typically presents with acute onset of severe pain, erythema, and swelling, most commonly affecting the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe), known as podagra. The patient's elevated serum uric acid and the use of hydrochlorothiazide, which can increase uric acid levels, further support the diagnosis of gout.

Option A: Pseudogout

Pseudogout is caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals, not monosodium urate. It often affects the knee or wrist, rather than the big toe, and typically presents in older patients. The synovial fluid analysis in pseudogout shows rhomboid-shaped crystals with positive birefringence under polarized light, which differentiates it from gout, where needle-shaped crystals with negative birefringence are seen.

Option B: Rheumatoid arthritis

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) usually presents with symmetrical joint involvement, particularly in the small joints of the hands and wrists. It rarely presents with an acute onset of symptoms in a single joint.

Additionally, RA typically causes chronic inflammation, morning stiffness lasting more than 1 hour, and does not affect the big toe as commonly as gout.

Option C: Septic arthritis

Septic arthritis can present with acute monoarthritis, but patients typically have fever, and the joint may be more diffusely swollen and tender than in gout.

The diagnosis is confirmed with joint aspiration, which shows purulent synovial fluid and an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count.

While this is an important differential diagnosis, the lack of fever and the patient's history of hyperuricemia make septic arthritis less likely.

Mnemonic for Gout:

'GRAPE':

  • G: Gout (caused by uric acid crystals)
  • R: Red (erythema in the affected joint)
  • A: Alcohol, diuretics as triggers
  • P: Podagra (big toe involvement)
  • E: Elevated serum uric acid levels

Key Takeaway:

  • Gout is a form of crystal-induced arthritis caused by monosodium urate crystal deposition in the joints, often triggered by dietary factors, medications, or metabolic conditions that increase serum uric acid levels.

References: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition,Page number:2464

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive difficulty in rising from a chair, combing her hair, and climbing stairs. On physical examination, she has a purple rash around her eyes and raised, scaly lesions on her knuckles.Laboratory tests reveal elevated creatine kinase (CK) and positive anti-Mi-2 antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dermatomyositis

Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune disease that affects both the skin and muscles. The hallmark signs are proximal muscle weakness (difficulty rising from a chair or climbing stairs) and specific skin findings like the heliotrope rash (purple discoloration around the eyes) and Gottron's papules (raised, scaly lesions over the knuckles). Elevated CK and specific autoantibodies like anti-Mi-2 also support the diagnosis. This patient's clinical presentation aligns closely with dermatomyositis.


Option A: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that can present with systemic symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, and a butterfly-shaped rash on the face.

However, muscle weakness and characteristic skin findings like the heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules are not typical of SLE.

SLE may involve muscles (myositis), but it does not usually present with the skin findings specific to dermatomyositis.

Option C: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)

RA typically affects the small joints of the hands and feet symmetrically, presenting with joint pain, swelling, and morning stiffness.

While RA can cause systemic symptoms like fatigue, it does not usually cause the proximal muscle weakness or the characteristic skin rash seen in dermatomyositis.

RA primarily involves joint inflammation, not muscle inflammation.

Option D: Psoriatic Arthritis

Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, a skin condition characterized by red, scaly patches.

Psoriatic arthritis commonly affects the joints, particularly with features like dactylitis (sausage digits). However, proximal muscle weakness and specific findings like the heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules are not associated with this condition. Therefore, psoriatic arthritis is not the correct diagnosis.


Key Features to Remember for Dermatomyositis:


Mnemonic:

Dermato (skin rash) + Myositis (muscle weakness) = Dermatomyositis.

Reference:Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2820

choices.text: Presence of lupus anticoagulant (LA) antibodies and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
Presence of anticardiolipin (aCL) antibodies and two consecutive pregnancy losses before 10 weeks of gestation
One clinical criterion (e.g., arterial thrombosis) and one laboratory criterion (e.g., anti-β2-glycoprotein I) on two occasions at least 12 weeks apart
Presence of anti-β2-glycoprotein I and thrombocytopenia

questions.text: Which of the following combinations is required to establish a diagnosis of Antiphospholipid Antibody (APLA) Syndrome ?
questions.solution:
C. One clinical criterion (e.g., arterial thrombosis) and one laboratory criterion (e.g., anti-β2-glycoprotein I) on two occasions at least 12 weeks apart:

Diagnosis requires at least one clinical event (vascular thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity) and one positive laboratory test (LA, aCL, or anti-β2-glycoprotein I) confirmed on two separate occasions 12 weeks apart.

A. Presence of lupus anticoagulant (LA) antibodies and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT):

While LA antibodies and a history of DVT are important components of the clinical and laboratory criteria, this option is incomplete.

For a diagnosis of APLA syndrome, both clinical and laboratory criteria must be met, and laboratory tests should be positive on two separate occasions at least 12 weeks apart.

B. Presence of anticardiolipin (aCL) antibodies and two consecutive pregnancy losses before 10 weeks of gestation:

This option describes an important part of the clinical criteria related to pregnancy morbidity, but a diagnosis also requires a corresponding laboratory finding, such as positive aCL or LA antibodies, detected on two separate occasions at least 12 weeks apart.

D. Presence of anti-β2-glycoprotein I and thrombocytopenia:

While anti-β2-glycoprotein I antibodies are part of the laboratory criteria for APLA syndrome, thrombocytopenia alone is not part of the clinical criteria required for diagnosis. Thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity must be present to meet the clinical criteria.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): APLA syndrome can be secondary to SLE, where patients may have similar clinical features like thrombosis or miscarriages.
  • Inherited Thrombophilias: Conditions like Factor V Leiden or prothrombin gene mutation can cause thrombosis but are differentiated by genetic testing.
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): DIC can also present with thrombosis and thrombocytopenia but usually occurs in the context of sepsis or malignancy.

Key to Remember / Mnemonics:

Mnemonic for APLA Diagnosis Criteria (Clinical + Lab):

  • "TAP-TAP"
    • T: Thrombosis (arterial/venous)
    • A: Adverse pregnancy outcome
    • P: Positive lab result (LA, aCL, anti-β2-glycoprotein I) on two occasions, 12 weeks apart


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2750

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is most specific for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and is associated with lupus nephritis?
questions.solution:
A. Anti-dsDNA:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for SLE and are often associated with lupus nephritis.

They are found in approximately 70% of patients with SLE and have a strong correlation with disease activity.

A positive result for anti-dsDNA is highly indicative of SLE, especially in patients presenting with renal involvement.

B. Antinuclear Antibody (ANA):

ANA is present in over 98% of patients with SLE, making it a highly sensitive marker.

However, ANA lacks specificity as it can also be found in other autoimmune conditions such as systemic sclerosis, Sjogren's syndrome, and even in healthy individuals.

A positive ANA result is useful for screening but not definitive for diagnosing SLE.

C. Anti-Sm:

Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for SLE but are present in only about 25-30% of patients.

While they are useful for diagnosing SLE, they are less frequently encountered compared to anti-dsDNA. Anti-Sm antibodies are not as closely associated with lupus nephritis as anti-dsDNA.

D. Anti-RNP:

Anti-RNP antibodies are not specific for SLE and are more commonly found in mixed connective tissue diseases.

Although anti-RNP can be present in some SLE patients, it is not a primary marker for diagnosing SLE and does not correlate strongly with lupus nephritis.


Differential Diagnosis:

  • Systemic Sclerosis: ANA can be positive, and specific antibodies like anti-centromere are useful in differentiating systemic sclerosis from SLE.
  • Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD): Anti-RNP antibodies are more commonly associated with MCTD, not SLE.
  • Sjogren's Syndrome: ANA may be positive, but anti-SSA (Ro) and anti-SSB (La) antibodies are more specific for Sjogren's.

Key to Remember:

Mnemonic for SLE-specific antibodies:

  • 'SLE = Sm & dsDNA'
  • S: Anti-Sm (specific for SLE)
  • L: Lupus nephritis associated with Anti-dsDNA
  • E: Elevated dsDNA in active disease

Quick Tip:

  • Anti-dsDNA = Nephritis and disease activity
  • ANA = Screening tool
  • Anti-Sm = Highly specific but less frequent

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2738

choices.text: Swan-neck deformity and ulnar deviation of the MCP joints
Heberden's nodes in the DIP joints
Involvement of the axial skeleton including the lumbar spine

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of morning stiffness lasting over 1 hour and symmetrical joint pain involving her hands and feet. Physical examination reveals swelling and tenderness in her metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. She has no involvement of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of her condition?
questions.solution:
Option A. Swan-neck deformity and ulnar deviation of the MCP joints:

Swan-neck deformity (hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint) and ulnar deviation of the MCP joints are characteristic deformities seen in advanced RA.

These deformities result from chronic inflammation and damage to the joints, tendons, and other soft tissues. Ulnar deviation is caused by subluxation of the MCP joints, commonly seen in RA patients.


B. Heberden's nodes in the DIP joints:

Heberden's nodes are bony enlargements of the DIP joints and are typically seen in osteoarthritis, not RA. While RA can occasionally involve the DIP joints, it primarily affects the MCP and PIP joints.


C. Positive anti-centromere antibodies:

Anti-centromere antibodies are associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), not RA.

In RA, patients may test positive for rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies.

D. Involvement of the axial skeleton including the lumbar spine:

RA rarely affects the lumbar or thoracic spine. In contrast, the cervical spine, particularly the atlantoaxial joint, can be involved, potentially leading to atlantoaxial subluxation.

Lumbar spine involvement is more characteristic of conditions like ankylosing spondylitis.


Differential Diagnosis:

  • Osteoarthritis: Characterized by Heberden's nodes (DIP involvement) and Bouchard's nodes (PIP involvement) but lacks the systemic inflammatory features of RA.
  • Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma): Associated with anti-centromere antibodies, not RF or anti-CCP antibodies.
  • Ankylosing Spondylitis: Involves axial skeleton, especially the sacroiliac joints and lumbar spine, unlike RA which spares the thoracic and lumbar spine.

Key to Remember:

Swan-neck and Boutonniere deformities are hallmark deformities of RA due to chronic joint inflammation.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2752

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is considered a Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drug (DMARD) of first choice for the treatment of early Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)?
questions.solution:
Option B (Methotrexate):
Methotrexate is the DMARD of first choice for the treatment of early RA due to its established efficacy in controlling disease activity and preventing joint damage. It is often the cornerstone of combination therapies in RA.

Methotrexate is the DMARD of choice for the treatment of RA and is the anchor drug for most combination therapies.

At the dosages used for the treatment of RA, methotrexate has been shown to stimulate adenosine release from cells, producing an anti-inflammatory effect.

Methotrexate is administered weekly by the oral or subcutaneous route. Folic acid is taken as co-therapy to mitigate some of methotrexate's side effects.

Methotrexate works by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase and has anti-inflammatory effects via the release of adenosine.


Option A (Hydroxychloroquine):

Hydroxychloroquine is a conventional DMARD used in the treatment of early and mild RA. However, it is not the first-line choice for aggressive disease or severe RA.

It is often used in combination with other DMARDs like methotrexate but does not significantly delay radiographic progression of the disease.

Option C (Tofacitinib):

Tofacitinib is a JAK inhibitor (targeted synthetic DMARD) used in RA, particularly for patients who do not respond to methotrexate or biologic therapies.

It is not considered first-line therapy and is typically introduced when there is an inadequate response to methotrexate.

Option D (Prednisone):

Prednisone is a glucocorticoid used in RA to control acute flares and provide rapid symptom relief. It is not classified as a DMARD and does not modify disease progression.

Long-term use of prednisone is generally discouraged due to its side effects, including osteoporosis and increased risk of infection.

Differential Diagnosis (DMARD Classes):



Key to Remember / Mnemonics / Easy Way to Remember:

"Methotrexate is the king of DMARDs"
Think of Methotrexate as the cornerstone for RA treatment, often referred to as the "anchor drug" in most regimens. It's the first-line DMARD, especially for early or active RA.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2752

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive tightening of the skin on her hands, face, and forearms. She also reports Raynaud's phenomenon and difficulty swallowing. Her examination reveals thickened skin limited to the face, forearms, and hands. Her serum shows positive anti-centromere antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. Limited Systemic Sclerosis (lSSc)

lSSc is characterized by skin involvement that is restricted to the face, neck, hands, and forearms.

Raynaud's phenomenon typically precedes other symptoms, and anti-centromere antibodies are common.

Gastrointestinal involvement such as dysphagia is common, but lung and kidney involvement is usually less severe compared to dSSc.


CREST syndrome seen in Limited Systemic sclerosis


B. Diffuse Systemic Sclerosis (dSSc)

dSSc involves rapid and widespread skin thickening that includes areas beyond the face, hands, and forearms, such as the trunk and upper arms.

It has more severe visceral involvement, including lung fibrosis and renal crisis, and is often associated with anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase) antibodies.

C. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease but lacks the characteristic skin tightening and Raynaud's phenomenon seen in systemic sclerosis.

SLE also presents with multi-organ involvement (kidney, joints, serosa, etc.), and antibodies like anti-dsDNA and anti-Smith are more common in SLE.

D. Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)

MCTD shares features with systemic sclerosis, SLE, and polymyositis, but it is associated with anti-U1-RNP antibodies.

Patients may have overlapping features but would not show the distinct clinical pattern of limited skin involvement seen in lSSc.



Multiorgan involvement in systemic sclerosis (SSc). Prominent complications of SSc: red, those more common in diffuse cutaneous SSc; black, those more common in limited cutaneous SSc; blue, complications common in both SSc subsets. GAVE, gastric antral vascular ectasia; GERD, gastroesophageal reflux disease; GI, gastrointestinal.

Key to Remember:

  • Limited Systemic Sclerosis: Skin involvement limited to the face, hands, and forearms. Often associated with Raynaud's phenomenon and anti-centromere antibodies.
  • Diffuse Systemic Sclerosis: Widespread skin involvement, including the trunk. Associated with more severe visceral organ involvement and anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase) antibodies.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2752

choices.text: CT scan of the sacroiliac joints

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with chronic low back pain for over 6 months. His symptoms are worse in the morning, lasting more than 30 minutes, and improve with physical activity. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the sacroiliac joints and reduced spinal flexibility. Laboratory tests show elevated C-reactive protein (CRP), and HLA-B27 is positive. Which imaging modality is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis of Ankylosing Spondylitis?
questions.solution:
C) MRI of the sacroiliac joints

MRI is the gold standard for diagnosing early Ankylosing Spondylitis.

MRI can detect early inflammatory changes such as bone marrow edema, soft tissue inflammation, and synovitis, even before structural damage occurs.

It is especially useful in detecting non-radiographic axial spondyloarthritis (nr-axSpA), where sacroilitis can be present without significant radiographic damage.

MRI helps visualize active inflammation in the sacroiliac joints and spine, confirming early-stage disease and allowing timely intervention to prevent progression.

MRI is the only imaging modality that can detect both early and active inflammation, which is crucial for diagnosing Ankylosing Spondylitis in its early stages.

It uses techniques like short tau inversion recovery (STIR) or T1-weighted images with contrast, making it sensitive for bone marrow edema and soft tissue changes.


A) X-ray of the lumbar spine

X-rays are typically used to assess structural damage in Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS), such as syndesmophytes (bony growths between vertebrae) or bamboo spine (fusion of the vertebrae).

However, these findings usually develop in the later stages of the disease.

In the early stages, sacroilitis (inflammation of the sacroiliac joints) may not be visible on X-ray. For early diagnosis, X-rays are not sensitive enough to detect soft tissue inflammation or bone marrow edema-hallmarks of early AS.

B) CT scan of the sacroiliac joints

CT scans are useful for detecting bony abnormalities such as erosions and structural changes, but they do not detect the active inflammation seen in early disease.

While CT provides excellent detail on bony structures, it is less effective for soft tissue inflammation and early inflammatory changes, which are crucial in diagnosing Ankylosing Spondylitis before permanent damage has occurred.

D) Bone scintigraphy

Bone scintigraphy (bone scan) involves injecting a small amount of radioactive material to detect areas of increased bone activity.

While this can show sites of inflammation, it is non-specific and lacks the detail needed to definitively diagnose Ankylosing Spondylitis. Other conditions, such as infections or malignancies, can cause increased uptake, making bone scintigraphy less specific than MRI for diagnosing AS.


Key Points for Diagnosis of Ankylosing Spondylitis:


Key Takeaways for Diagnosis:

  • MRI of the sacroiliac joints is crucial for early diagnosis of Ankylosing Spondylitis, especially when X-rays are negative.
  • Early detection and treatment are important to reduce the risk of long-term complications like spinal fusion and disability.
  • Inflammatory markers like CRP are often elevated in active disease, but imaging remains the cornerstone of diagnosis, particularly in early cases.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2794

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with fatigue, night sweats, and muscle pain. On examination, her blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg in the right arm and 130/80 mmHg in the left arm. Pulses are diminished in the left radial artery, and a bruit is heard over the subclavian region. Laboratory findings show an elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Takayasu's Arteritis

Takayasu's arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that commonly affects young women, primarily involving the aorta and its major branches, including the subclavian and carotid arteries.

Characteristic clinical findings include diminished or absent pulses, discrepancies in blood pressure between arms, and arterial bruits.

The elevated ESR and symptoms like fatigue and muscle pain are consistent with systemic inflammation caused by Takayasu's arteritis.

Option A: Polyarteritis Nodosa

Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing vasculitis affecting small- and medium-sized arteries, typically involving visceral arteries.

Patients usually present with systemic symptoms like fever, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement, but they rarely exhibit differences in blood pressure between arms or bruits over large vessels, as seen in this case. Moreover, it does not usually involve the aortic arch or its branches.

Option B: Giant Cell Arteritis

Giant cell arteritis typically affects older adults (>50 years) and presents with headache, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances.

It involves large arteries like the temporal artery but is not typically associated with the blood pressure discrepancies and diminished pulses in the upper limbs seen in this case.

Option D: Buerger's Disease

Buerger's disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) affects small- and medium-sized vessels in the extremities, usually in young men who smoke.

It is characterized by ischemia, ulcers, and gangrene in the hands and feet but does not involve the large arteries or present with blood pressure discrepancies between limbs.

Key features regarding Takayasu's arteritis



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2813

questions.text: Which of the following is a common systemic manifestation of primary Sjogren's syndrome?
questions.solution:
C) Raynaud's phenomenon

Raynaud's phenomenon is a common systemic manifestation of Sjogren's syndrome, occurring in about 37% of patients.

It often precedes the development of sicca symptoms (dry eyes and mouth) and involves episodic vasospasm of the fingers and toes, leading to color changes and discomfort in response to cold or stress.

A) Glomerulonephritis

While renal involvement can occur in Sjogren's syndrome, it typically manifests as interstitial nephritis rather than glomerulonephritis.

Interstitial nephritis leads to renal tubular dysfunction and occasionally renal tubular acidosis.

Glomerulonephritis is more associated with conditions like lupus nephritis in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

B) Pulmonary artery involvement

Pulmonary involvement in Sjogren's syndrome typically includes small airway disease, bronchitis sicca, and interstitial lung disease, but pulmonary artery involvement is not characteristic of Sjogren's syndrome.

Pulmonary artery involvement is more common in diseases like Takayasu arteritis or pulmonary hypertension.

D) Cardiomyopathy

Cardiomyopathy is not a common manifestation of Sjogren's syndrome. While Sjogren's can increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, cardiomyopathy is more associated with other conditions like sarcoidosis or idiopathic cardiomyopathies.

The cardiovascular risks in Sjogren's are more related to accelerated atherosclerosis or vasculitis.


Key features of Sjogren's syndrome


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2788

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic radiographic finding in patients with Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA)?
questions.solution:
Option C:

This is a classical radiographic finding in Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA), especially in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints. It occurs due to severe erosion and bone resorption, leading to a tapered appearance of one bone end that fits into a cup-shaped deformity of the adjacent bone.


Option A: Symmetric sacroilitis

Symmetric sacroilitis is more characteristic of Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS), not PsA.

In PsA, sacroilitis tends to be asymmetric.

PsA can affect the sacroiliac joints but does so in a more asymmetric fashion compared to AS.


Ankylosing Spondyolitis

Option B: Marginal syndesmophytes

Marginal syndesmophytes are more characteristic of Ankylosing Spondylitis, while in PsA, syndesmophytes are usually non-marginal, bulky, and asymmetric.

PsA has distinct radiographic features compared to AS.


Option D: Juxta-articular osteoporosis

This feature is more commonly associated with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) and is less specific for PsA. PsA is characterized more by bone proliferation (periostitis) rather than osteoporosis.


Key to remember

Pencil-in-cup deformity is a hallmark feature of PsA and can help differentiate it from other forms of arthritis such as RA or AS.

Differential diagnosis of PsA



Key features of psoaratic arthritis


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2800

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with acute knee pain, swelling, and redness. He reports that the pain began suddenly two days ago and has progressively worsened. He has a history of osteoarthritis but denies trauma or fever. Synovial fluid analysis reveals rhomboid-shaped crystals that are weakly positively birefringent under polarized light. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
B) Pseudogout

Pseudogout, also known as calcium pyrophosphate deposition (CPPD) disease, typically presents in older individuals with acute joint pain and inflammation, most commonly affecting the knee.

The hallmark of pseudogout is the presence of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals, which are rhomboid-shaped and weakly positively birefringent under polarized light. This matches the findings in the patient.

Key aspects of Pseudogout


A) Gout

Gout is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals. These crystals are needle-shaped and strongly negatively birefringent under polarized light microscopy, which is different from the rhomboid-shaped crystals found in this case.

C) Septic arthritis

Septic arthritis involves joint infection, usually with bacteria, leading to a painful, swollen, and warm joint. Synovial fluid in septic arthritis typically shows a high white blood cell count, and crystal analysis would not reveal CPP crystals.

Septic arthritis requires a positive culture or other signs of infection. Thus, this is not the correct diagnosis.

D) Rheumatoid arthritis

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory arthritis that typically affects smaller joints in a symmetrical pattern. It is not associated with crystal deposition in the joints and does not present with acute monoarticular joint pain. Synovial fluid analysis would not show crystals.

Note: Polarized light microscopy Gout vs Pseudogout.



A. Extracellular and intracellular monosodium urate crystals, as seen in a fresh preparation of synovial fluid, illustrate needle- and rod-shaped crystals (400×). These crystals are strongly negative birefringent crystals under compensated polarized light microscopy.

B. Intracellular and extracellular calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals, as seen in a fresh preparation of synovial fluid, illustrate rectangular, rod-shaped, and rhomboid crystals (400×). These crystals are weakly positively or nonbirefringent crystals under compensated polarized light microscopy

Reference:Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2866

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, and hemoptysis. His urine analysis reveals hematuria and proteinuria. Laboratory tests show elevated creatinine and a positive anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA) test with a cytoplasmic staining pattern (c-ANCA). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)

GPA (formerly Wegener's granulomatosis) is a type of ANCA-associated vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas in the respiratory tract, kidneys, and other organs.

It is strongly associated with c-ANCA and anti-proteinase-3 (PR3) antibodies.

The presence of hemoptysis, renal involvement, and a positive c-ANCA test suggests GPA.



B) Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)

MPA is another form of ANCA-associated vasculitis, but it typically presents with p-ANCA positivity (anti-myeloperoxidase, MPO). MPA lacks the granulomatous inflammation seen in GPA and does not commonly involve the upper respiratory tract.

C) Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA)

EGPA (formerly Churg-Strauss syndrome) is characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and vasculitis. It is often associated with p-ANCA and affects multiple organs, including the lungs.

However, this patient lacks the eosinophilia and asthma typically seen in EGPA, making this diagnosis less likely.

D) Goodpasture syndrome

Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies, not ANCA. It typically presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis, but it is distinguished from ANCA-associated vasculitis by the presence of anti-GBM antibodies. Since the patient has c-ANCA positivity, this is not the correct answer.

Differential Diagnosis:


Key to Remember/Mnemonics/Easy Way to Remember:

  • GPA: "Granulomas, Proteinase-3, Airway involvement" → c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) positive.
  • MPA: "Minimal Granulomas, Pulmonary, p-ANCA" → p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA) positive.
  • EGPA: "Eosinophils, Granulomas, p-ANCA" → Asthma and eosinophilia.
  • Goodpasture syndrome: "Goodpasture = Goodbyes to both lungs and kidneys" → Anti-GBM antibodies.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page Number.2806
